1.4 Five-Year Accident History

There have been no qualifying accidental releases at the site over the last five years.  There is no data to report.

1.5 The Emergency Response Program

The Emergency Response Program is divided into two elements, as only properly trained and qualified personnel are authorized to respond to emergencies.  Personnel are trained to notify and evacuate via the Emergency Action Plan.  Only the Fire Department would respond to an emergency; support would be made available via WPS personnel trained to 29 CFR 1910.120(q) standards.  Emergency equipment is maintained under the control of WPS.  Written ammonia emergency response procedures are detailed in the facilitys Thirty Minute Plan.  Appropriately written plans are maintained on-site and updated on a regular basis.  Local Emergency Response capabilities have been verified. The Yuma area has a Haz-Mat Response Team and Mutual Aid Agreement.

ic at the tanks.  In 1997 an automated water system was installed to help cool the tanks on extremely hot days (120 degrees F+) or periods of prolonged high heat.  The water system provides evaporative cooling of the tank skin which reduces the pressure in the vessel.  Pressure Relief Valves are installed on the vessels per the applicable codes.

Maintenance is performed on the vessels and/or associated equipment in the winter months when they are usually empty.  New pressure relief valves are scheduled for installation every 5 years per industry standards.   A vapor compressor and 3-way valve system provide the means to transfer refrigerant to or from the vessels.  The compressor and hose system is inspected regularly for damage, wear, and tear.  Locked storage for transfer hoses was added in January 2004.  The evaporative cooling water systems actuator switch is tested annually for proper operation. 

Other release prevention steps taken at WPS - Yuma Shop:
?	The storage vessel system at WPS/Yuma Shop differs from other storage systems (fertilizer terminals) in this way. The transfer activity takes place during a few weeks per year whereas a typical terminal will have daily transfer activity. WPS feels that this minimum number of transfers provides a reduction in risk and exposure.

?	Only SOP-trained technicians are authorized to perform transfer activities.
?	Policy requires two or more qualified personnel present to perform transfers.

ides ammonia refrigeration services and equipment to many of the seasonally operated Produce Cooler operations, Partners, & Equipment Customers. Two ammonia storage vessels are used for temporary seasonal storage of ammonia.  The first of the two storage vessels was placed on-site in 1988.  The second vessel was acquired in 1994.  These vessels are ASME Certified.

Produce growing and shipping is a seasonal event in Yuma.  Typically, fresh vegetables come into season in November and finish in April.  When cooling equipment is taken out of service in the spring, the refrigerant is transferred out of that equipment and stored in vessels at WPS-Yuma Shop.  The vessels are rated for ammonia service and are equipped with isolation and Pressure Relief Valves installed in accordance with applicable codes. The only Regulated Substance stored is anhydrous ammonia (NH3).  

1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Accidental Release Prevention Program

A comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM) has been established for the site, in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119.  The PSM Program is specifically intended to promote the safe operation of ammonia-handling equipment and processes.  PSM is an integral part of the Storage Facility operation.  The facility does not qualify for the PSM Program (>10,000 lbs NH3) during ON Season (Fall/Winter: November  April). At that time the ammonia is being used in off-site equipment. Storage in excess of 10,000 pounds is during OFF Season (Spring/Summer: May  October). 

WPS actively encourages its ammonia technicians to seek Certification through the Refrigeration Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA).

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN LEVEL 3
5-YEAR UPDATE APRIL 2024

1	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Western Precooling SystemsYuma Shop (WPS) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply not to have accidental releases or emergencies.  The company endeavors to execute these policies through the implementation of its Safety Program.  The company safety program includes but is not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management (PSM).  PSM is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases.  It is the primary goal of WPS to protect employees, visitors, and neighbors from harm due to company operations.

WPS has adopted a non-responding facility policy; has an established Emergency Action Plan and has taken the steps necessary to be included in the community emergency plan.  An Emergency Coordinator has been established and coordination with the State Emergency Response Commission (SERC), Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Fire Department is performed on an ongoing basis.  Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated and kept current through the annual submittal of appropriate Reports, involvement with Fire Department and LEPC planning Yuma Ammonia Safety Days, and periodic tours of the facility.  

WPS policy also includes maintaining appropriate emergency capabilities and to deal with emergencies safely if and when they do happen.  Key WPS employees attend 1910.120 (q) Emergency Response training that is refreshed annually.  Emergency equipment is maintained under the control of WPS.  The company strives to execute its emergency response policies through skilled employees that are provided with adequate and appropriate equipment and training.
